questions.text: The audiogram given in the image below is seen in___________?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endolymphatic hydrops The given audiogram shows an upsloping result/rising curve which is seen in Meniere’s disease aka endolymphatic hydrops.

Highyeild:

Meniere's disease is also called endolymphatic hydrops Excess pressure accumulation in the endolymph can cause a tetrad of symptoms: Fluctuating hearing loss, Occasional episodic vertigo Tinnitus or ringing in the ears Aural fullness Fig-Aetiological factors of Meniere’s disease Intolerance to loud sounds known as the recruitment phenomenon is characteristic of all cochlear pathologies. Diplacusis is the perception of a single auditory stimulus as sounds of different pitch in both the ears. Tullio’s phenomenon is where loud sounds produce vertigo. Early Meniere’s affects lower frequency first. SP/AP potential greater than 0.4 or 0.5 are consistent with the diagnosis of Meniere’s disease. Audiogram in early Meniere’s Disease. Hearing loss is sensorineural and more in lower frequencies – the rising curve. As the disease progresses, middle and higher frequencies get involved and audiogram becomes flat or falling type (B & C) Investigations: Tuning forks tests: SNHL PTA Speech audiometry Recruitment test + ve SISI > 70 % Tone decay < 20 Db

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A- NIHL (Noise induced hearing loss)-The audiogram in NIHL shows a typical notch, at 4 kHz, both for air and bone conduction Option: B- Ototoxicity- Option: D- Presbycusis- Most commonly, the audiogram shows a hearing loss which tends to be worse at the higher frequencies.

Extraedge:

Intermittent Low-Pressure Pulse Therapy [Meniett Device Therapy] Intermittent positive pressure delivered to inner ear fluids brings relief from the symptoms of Ménière’s disease. There is improvement in vertigo, tinnitus and ear fullness and hearing. Intermittent positive pressure waves can be delivered through an instrument called Meniett device which has been approved by FDA. Prerequisite: Myringotomy and insert a ventilation tube so that the device when coupled to the external ear canal can deliver pressure waves to the round window membrane via the ventilation tube. Pressure waves pass through the perilymph and cause reduction in endolymph pressure by redistributing it through various communication channels such as the endolymphatic sac or the blood vessels

questions.text: A woman presents with bilateral hearing loss which is more in the right ear than the left. She is diagnosed with otosclerosis. What will be the possible tuning fork test?

options.label: A
options.text: B/L Rinne positive Weber lateralized to right

options.label: B
options.text: Right side Rinne negative Weber lateralized to right

options.label: C
options.text: Right side Rinne positive Weber lateralized to left

options.label: D
options.text: B/L Rinne negative Weber lateralized to left

questions.correct_answer: B. Right side Rinne negative Weber lateralized to right
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Right side Rinne negative Weber lateralized to right Rinne test is negative in c/o otosclerosis & weber is always lateralized to the worst ear i.e. right ear in his case.

Highyeild:

Otosclerosis Otosclerosis, more aptly called otospongiosis, is a primary disease of the bony labyrinth. In this, one or more foci of irregularly laid spongy bone replace part of normally dense enchondral layer of bony otic capsule Types : Stapedial , Cochlear , Histologic Fig - Types of stapedial otosclerosis. (A) Anterior focus. (B) Posterior focus. (C) Circumferential. (D) Biscuit type (thick plate).(E) Obliterative. Symptoms - Hearing loss, Paracusis willisii , tinnitus , vertigo , speech Otoscopic findings in otosclerosis : The tympanic membrane is normal and mobile in 90% of cases. Schwartz signs—Flamingo pink in the tympanic membrane is seen in 10% of cases. It indicates active Focus with increased vascularity. Stapes footplate—Shows a rice grain/biscuit-type appearance Blue mantles are seen histopathologically. Treatment : Surgical. Stapedectomy/stapedotomy with a placement of prosthesis is the treatment of choice. Here the fixed otosclerotic stapes is removed and a prosthesis inserted between the incus and oval window Prosthesis employed may be a teflon piston, stainless steel piston, platinum–teflon or titanium–teflon piston

Extraedge:

Selection of Patients for Stapes Surgery. Hearing threshold for air conduction should be 30 dB or worse. Average air-bone gap should be at least 15 dB with Rinne negative for 256 and 512 Hz. Speech discrimination score should be 60% or more.

Table:

#MANTRA Complications of Stapedectomy Tear of tympanomeatal flap and later perforation of tympanic membrane Injury to chorda tympani with taste disturbance particularly if opposite chorda was earlier injured Incus dislocation Injury to facial nerve Vertigo Early in postoperative period (intraoperative trauma, serous labyrinthitis, long prosthesis) Late due to perilymph fistula and benign paroxysmal positional vertigo Perilymph fistula/granuloma Conductive loss Short prosthesis Loose prosthesis

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents with hearing loss. He is able to hear speech, only while shouting or when it is amplified. What is the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Profound hearing loss with more than 70%disability

options.label: B
options.text: Moderate hearing loss with less than 50% disability

options.label: C
options.text: Severe hearing loss with more than 70% disability

questions.correct_answer: C. Severe hearing loss with more than 70% disability
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Severe hearing loss with more than 70% disability Mild hearing loss - <60 db (cannot hear low intensity sound) Moderate hearing loss - <70 db (cannot hear normal speech) Severe hearing loss – 71 – 90 db (can hear only amplified sounds) Profound hearing loss - >90 db (cannot hear amplified sounds as well)

Highyeild:

Hearing threshold in better ear (average of 500, 1000, 2000 Hz) Degree of impairment (WHO classification) Ability to understand speech 0-25 Not significant No significant difficulty with faint speech 26-40 Mild Difficulty with faint speech 41-55 Moderate Frequent difficulty with normal speech 56-70 Moderately severe Frequent difficulty even with loud speech 71-90 Severe Can understand only shouted or amplified speech 91 above Profound Usually cannot understand even amplified speech

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A- Profound hearing loss with more than 70%disability-Profound is >90% Option: B- Moderate hearing loss with less than 50% disability-Moderate is 41-55% Option: D- Intermediate hearing loss with 30% disability-There is no intermediate in WHO classification

questions.text: A 7-year-old male presents with progressive bulging of the left eye with a diminution of vision since 1 day. He has a history of URTI and on examination, it is seen that he also has nasal congestion with active discharge. The CT scan of the PNS is seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sinusitis with subperiosteal abscess According to the given clinical picture & CT image, sinusitis with subperiosteal abscess is the most probable diagnosis. There is haziness in the ethmoid sinuses which is suggestive of sinusitis The CT image shows collection between the periorbita and orbital wall, hence subperiosteal abscess

Highyeild:

Fig - (a) preseptal inflammation; (b) orbital cellulitis; (c) orbital cellulitis with subperiosteal (extra periosteal) abscess; (d) orbital cellulitis with intra-periosteal abscess; (e) cavernous sinus thrombosis. Red and yellow shading indicate inflammation/cellulitis, and green shading indicates pus.

Extraedge:

Chandler stages Stage 1 Stage 2 Stage 3 Stage 4 Stage 5 Preseptal cellulitis Postseptal cellulitis or orbital cellulitis without abscess Subperiosteal abscess Orbital abscess Cavernous sinus thrombosis/abscess Inflammation does not extend beyond the orbital septum (where the medial orbital periosteal reflection attaches to the medial eyelid at the tarsal plate). Inflammation extends into the tissues of the orbit. There is abscess formation deep to the periosteum of the orbital bones, typically at the lamina papyracea from ethmoid sinusitis. There is abscess formation within the orbit which has breached the periosteum. The inflammatory process has extended into the cavernous sinus which thromboses and may progress to abscess formation.

questions.text: A South Indian male cattle breeder comes with complaints of frank intermittent epistaxis. The examination of the nose is given below. A biopsy was taken and HPE appears as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rhinosporidiosis With the given clinical image & HPE finding, the most likely diagnosis is rhinosporidiosis, caused by the organism – Rhinosporidium seeberi.

Highyeild:

Rhinosporidium seeberi was previously considered a fungus. It is now taken as an aquatic protistan protozoan. It belongs to the class mesomycetozoea and is unicellular. This is acquired by contaminated water from ponds also frequented by animals. In India, disease is more common in the southern states. It is prevalent in the states of Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Puducherry and Andhra Pradesh. Features of mass - Leafy Polypoidal mass, pink to purple in colour and attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia of the organism Diagnosis: Biopsy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A- Nasal polyp-Nasal polypi are non-neoplastic masses of oedematous nasal or sinus mucosa Option: C- Hemangioma-It is a soft, dark red, pedunculated or sessile tumour arising from the anterior part of nasal septum Option: D- Rhinophyma-Rhinophyma is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands of the nasal tip

Extraedge:

Image showing life cycle of Rhinosporidium seeberi

questions.text: Which of the following statements BEST describes otoacoustic emissions?

options.label: A
options.text: OAEs represent sound generated by the outer hair cells.

options.label: B
options.text: In cochlear disease OAE is normal.

options.label: C
options.text: OAE is present in 100% of individuals.

options.label: D
options.text: In neonatal screening the demonstration of OAEs excludes severe ear SNHL.

questions.correct_answer: A. OAEs represent sound generated by the outer hair cells.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

OAEs represent sound generated by the outer hair cells. Otoacoustic emissions represent sound generated by the outer hair cells, typically in response to a sound stimulus. OAE are used to differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear disease.

Highyeild:

OTOACOUSTIC EMISSIONS Tells about Cochlear function OAE produced by Outer Hair Cells of Cochlea. OAE is used to differentiate Cochlear disease from Retrocochlear disease If OAE is normal it’s a Retrocochlear disease

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. In cochlear disease OAE is abnormal. In retrocochlear disease OAE is normal. Option: C. OAEs are absent in 50% of normal individuals. Option: D. The emissions are frequently absent in conductive hearing loss and are usually absent in severe SNHL although they do not exclude an absent cochlear nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are correct about hair cells? There is 1 row of inner hair cells and 3 rows of outer hair cells Inner hair cells are responsible for transmitting auditory impulses Majority of the afferent fibres of spiral ganglion supply the inner hair cells. Outer hair cells primarily initiate the electrical signals sent to the brain in response to sound vibrations. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

i, ii, iii There are 3-4 layers of outer hair cells in the organ of corti in the inner ear. Fig - Organ of corti

Highyeild:

They are important receptor cells of hearing and transduce sound energy into electrical energy. Inner hair cells form a single row while outer hair cells are arranged in three or four rows. Inner hair cells are richly supplied by afferent cochlear fibres and are probably more important in the transmission of auditory impulses. Outer hair cells mainly receive efferent innervation from the olivary complex and are concerned with modulating the function of inner hair cells. DIFFERENCES BETWEEN INNER AND OUTER HAIR CELLS Inner hair cells Outer hair cells Total no. 3500 12,000 Rows One row Three or four rows Shape Flask shaped Cylindrical Nerve supply Primarily afferent fibres and very few efferent Mainly efferent fibres and very few afferent Development Develop earlier Develop late Function Transmit auditory stimuli Modulate function of inner hair cells Vulnerability More resistant Easily damaged by ototoxic drugs and high intensity noise
